messages.content: Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë aheai"

"The natural English translation for 'thë aheai' is 'the sun is rising'.
Literal: 'The sun rises'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë aheo"
"The natural English translation for 'thë aheo' is 'the sun is setting'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma"

"The natural English translation for 'pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma' is 'the children are playing with the puppy'.
Literal: 'Children small the puppy with the play play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë yesi kë iha a ahetou"
"The natural English translation for 'pë yesi kë iha a ahetou' is 'you should go and get some bananas'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema"

"The natural English translation for 'ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema' is 'I'm going to make a new house'.
Literal: 'I house new I make'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "hãtõ ya nahiki aheamai kuprei"

"The natural English translation for 'hãtõ ya nahiki aheamai kuprei' is 'the children are playing in the river'.
Literal: 'Children the river in playing'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "warë këki aheare kë thë"
"The natural English translation for 'warë këki aheare kë thë' is 'the children are playing in the sun'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë ki napë no wãri ahepi ma rë mai"
"The natural English translation for 'thë ki napë no wãri ahepi ma rë mai' is 'the sun is very hot today and I'm sweating a lot'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma"

"The natural English translation for 'ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma' is 'When you go to the forest, be careful not to get lost, and bring back some fruit'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yëtu kë yamaki rë mi ãmõãhãrayopërei"

"The natural English translation for 'yëtu kë yamaki rë mi ãmõãhãrayopërei' is 'you should not go to the village alone'.
Literal: 'You not go village alone should'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "rë ahetepraruhe"
"The natural English translation for 'rë ahetepraruhe' is 'you are a good person'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "te meteré (lit. te plans ho ko re w ë"

"The natural English translation for 'te meteré' is 'I am hungry'.
Literal: 'My stomach is empty'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "rë henaopoi (cha.)"

"The natural English translation for 'rë henaopoi (cha.)' is 'you are beautiful (woman)'.
Literal: 'You beautiful (woman)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "hei ya shikãpi rë rëre hami"

"The natural English translation for 'hei ya shikãpi rë rëre hami' is 'you are a good hunter'.
Literal: 'You good hunter are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "hei ai yoka rë horere"

"The natural English translation for 'hei ai yoka rë horere' is 'the child is playing outside'.
Literal: 'Child outside play is doing'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pata ma rë tirorotamayoruu tharei"

"The natural English translation for 'pata ma rë tirorotamayoruu tharei' is 'the children are playing in the river'.
Literal: 'children the river in playing are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "rë uprayahi ha"
"The natural English translation for 'rë uprayahi ha' is 'you are a good person'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yaro kahiki rë keonowei thë yãno pë si ahi nikerei"
"The natural English translation for 'yaro kahiki rë keonowei thë yãno pë si ahi nikerei' is 'the children are playing in the village plaza under the hot sun'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "wa rii ha rãrini ãhi teshi ta thapa"
"The natural English translation for 'wa rii ha rãrini ãhi teshi ta thapa' is 'I'm going to the forest to hunt and bring back animal meat'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ama ãsi"
"The natural English translation for 'ama ãsi' is 'my mother'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yëtu kë thë urihi ahetetaremam a h e"

"The natural English translation for 'yëtu kë thë urihi ahetetaremam a h e' is 'the children are playing in the river'.
Literal: 'children the river in playing are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yëtu thë urihi ahetetai rë kõrãyouwei, puhipuhi pëni (mit.)"

"The natural English translation for 'yëtu thë urihi ahetetai rë kõrãyouwei, puhipuhi pëni (mit.)' is 'The children are playing and running around the house, they are very happy (myth)'.
Literal: 'Children the house around run play, very happy (myth)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë henaki ha ahetetamarini, henaki wakë piyëmakema, pothothe , yopri puu naki hisikikema"

"The natural English translation for 'thë henaki ha ahetetamarini, henaki wakë piyëmakema, pothothe, yopri puu naki hisikikema' is 'The sun is high in the sky, the sun's rays are strong, it's very hot, and we are sweating a lot'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë përia ahetea"
"The natural English translation for 'pë përia ahetea' is 'you are a good person'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "warë kë ki hiraa ahetea"

"The natural English translation for 'warë kë ki hiraa ahetea' is 'the children are playing outside'.
Literal: 'children the outside play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "wa ahetepraa totihia kë a kure"
"The natural English translation for 'wa ahetepraa totihia kë a kure' is 'I'm going to the river to fish with a hook'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yoka ãhiãi"
"The natural English translation for 'yoka ãhiãi' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë mi titi"
"The natural English translation for 'thë mi titi' is 'the sun is hot'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãimawë no wãri kë ki huhehea waikirayonowë, pëhëki yashuprai waikirayou kë a kuhe (cha.)"

"The natural English translation for 'ãimawë no wãri kë ki huhehea waikirayonowë, pëhëki yashuprai waikirayou kë a kuhe (cha.)' is 'The children are playing in the river, splashing water at each other (laughing)'.
Literal: 'Children the river in playing splashing water each other at (laughing)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãiwëni hoya kë a wai tharei kuroi"

"The natural English translation for 'ãiwëni hoya kë a wai tharei kuroi' is 'The woman is cooking banana soup for the children'.
Literal: 'Woman banana soup for children cooking'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãiwë a wãri iha kamiyë ya roo aheteo"
"The natural English translation for 'ãiwë a wãri iha kamiyë ya roo aheteo' is 'The children are playing in the river with their friends'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure"
"The natural English translation for 'yei kë ãmo wai wãnipraa kure' is 'let's go to the river to fish with hooks'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)"

"The natural English translation for 'ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)' is 'The children are playing in the village (outside)'.
Literal: 'Children the village in play (outside)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari"

"The natural English translation for 'kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari' is 'Yesterday I went to the river to fish, but I didn't catch any fish and came back empty-handed'.
Literal: 'Yesterday I go river fish, but no fish catch come back empty-handed'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ei kõpina nari pë rë ãiãmorãti, a huu ta mi (wayamou, diálogo ceremonial.)"

"The natural English translation for 'ei kõpina nari pë rë ãiãmorãti, a huu ta mi (wayamou, diálogo ceremonial.)' is 'This is the story of our ancestors, the wayamou ceremonial dialogue'.
Literal: 'This story ancestors our tell, wayamou ceremonial dialogue'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "himo kë ki ãiãmoprou ha kuparuni (cha.)"

"The natural English translation for 'himo kë ki ãiãmoprou ha kuparuni (cha.)' is 'my child is crying because he/she is hungry'.
Literal: 'My child crying because hungry (diminutive)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãiãmo hena(ki) ... La planta se pone a secar y las hojas se pulverizan, luego se inhala el polvo, solo o mezclado, como alucinógeno."

"The natural English translation for 'ãiãmo hena(ki) ... La planta se pone a secar y las hojas se pulverizan, luego se inhala el polvo, solo o mezclado, como alucinógeno' is 'The plant is dried and the leaves are powdered, then the powder is inhaled, either alone or mixed, as a hallucinogen'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa"

"The natural English translation for 'aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa' is 'I'm going to the river to fish and bring back fish'.
Literal: 'I go to river fish bring'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "aka moyepi kë thë"

"The natural English translation for 'aka moyepi kë thë' is 'the child is eating banana'.
Literal: 'child banana eating is'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "aka hõprai"
"The natural English translation for 'aka hõprai' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pei kë ma pë pata namo shirikiopë hami shamariwë a pata akatahu yapikirariyoma (mit.)"

"The natural English translation for 'pei kë ma pë pata namo shirikiopë hami shamariwë a pata akatahu yapikirariyoma (mit.)' is 'Don't go to the village, there are many shamans and they will bewitch you (myth)'.
Literal: 'Don't you go village there shaman many they bewitch you (myth)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "akrëhë akrëtëai"
"The natural English translation for 'akrëhë akrëtëai' is 'I'm hungry'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe"

"The natural English translation for 'thë hena pë ta yototoamapotuhe' is 'the children are playing outside'.
Literal: 'The children outside play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya thë u ha koarini"
"The natural English translation for 'ya thë u ha koarini' is 'I'm going to get water from the river'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya thë pouku wãri ha totihiarini"

"The natural English translation for 'ya thë pouku wãri ha totihiarini' is 'you are going to cook the banana in the pot'.
Literal: 'You banana pot in cook will'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pei thë u aheteprao ha yairini"

"The natural English translation for 'pei thë u aheteprao ha yairini' is 'the children are playing in the river'.
Literal: 'Children the river in playing are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë no ha tetetaruni a kõrãyõma"

"The natural English translation for 'thë no ha tetetaruni a kõrãyõma' is 'the children are playing in the village'.
Literal: 'The children play in village'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë ta shëyëpa"
"The natural English translation for 'thë ta shëyëpa' is 'the sun is setting'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë hipëpema"
"The natural English translation for 'thë hipëpema' is 'the sun is setting'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë thë pë puﬁ wãri hore tikrohai si ihehewë"

"The natural English translation for 'pë thë pë puﬁ wãri hore tikrohai si ihehewë' is 'you should not go out alone in the forest at night'.
Literal: 'You you not go forest night danger animal bad'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë ki ta këprari, pei kë siki"
"The natural English translation for 'thë ki ta këprari, pei kë siki' is 'the sun is hot today, let's go to the river'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë thë patherio kõõpë kë"

"The natural English translation for 'pë thë patherio kõõpë kë' is 'you are a good hunter'.
Literal: 'You the hunter good are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "preyura kë pëni pë thë haromai totihio tharei"

"The natural English translation for 'preyura kë pëni pë thë haromai totihio tharei' is 'the children are playing in the river with their friends'.
Literal: 'Children the river in the friends with playing'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "he pëprai"

"The natural English translation for 'he pëprai' is 'it's raining'.
Literal: 'Rain falls'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "fimiki pëo"
"The natural English translation for 'fimiki pëo' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë owëai tëhë pë yãrimou kãi hiraoma"

"The natural English translation for 'pë owëai tëhë pë yãrimou kãi hiraoma' is 'you should go to the river and catch some fish for us'.
Literal: 'You go river you catch fish for us'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "warapawë yawëroopë, wa pë maikaprari"
The natural English translation for 'warapawë yawëroopë, wa pë maikaprari' is 'My friend, I'm going to visit you'.
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë shëi mai kë thë"

"The natural English translation for 'pë shëi mai kë thë' is 'you are a good person'.
Literal: 'You person good be that'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë no tarema"
"The natural English translation for 'pë no tarema' is 'you are a good person'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë puhii"
"The natural English translation for 'pë puhii' is 'you are good'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë mii mi huma"
"The natural English translation for 'pë mii mi huma' is 'you are eating banana'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "kuo pëo"
"The natural English translation for 'kuo pëo' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "horehore p∫∫ kë nahe wãri thatathatapia ha pëkini"

"The natural English translation for 'horehore p∫∫ kë nahe wãri thatathatapia ha pëkini' is 'the children are playing and running around the village'.
Literal: 'Children small village around run-run-REDUP and play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya mishiã mrai yaio pëa"

"The natural English translation for 'ya mishiã mrai yaio pëa' is 'give me some banana fruit'.
Literal: 'You banana fruit give me'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "pë ha prawëpë ha f–pramopë ha"

"The natural English translation for 'pë ha prawëpë ha f–pramopë ha' is 'you go to the river and bathe'.
Literal: 'You go river bathe'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "hotho pë tërëkou"
"The natural English translation for 'hotho pë tërëkou' is 'the child is crying'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "e naha thë pë imiki rë hurukanowei, thë pë ãhã rë yehipore"

"The natural English translation for 'e naha thë pë imiki rë hurukanowei, thë pë ãhã rë yehipore' is 'You should not go near the river, there are many piranhas there'.
Literal: 'You not should river to go near, there piranha many are'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "shee pë shirõ yãmonashi uku"

"The natural English translation for 'shee pë shirõ yãmonashi uku' is 'the child is playing with a small stick'.
Literal: 'child with stick small playing is'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "opo si ãikiwë kë a wai amishiri yakarema (mit.)"

"The natural English translation for 'opo si ãikiwë kë a wai amishiri yakarema (mit.)' is 'my friend, you should not go to that dangerous place'.
Literal: 'Friend my, you not go place dangerous that (myth)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama (mit.) (habla del sur del Orinoco.)"

"The natural English translation for 'rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama (mit.) (habla del sur del Orinoco.)' is 'the shaman is singing the chant to call the spirits of the forest'.
Literal: 'shaman sing chant call spirits forest (myth) (speech from south of Orinoco River)'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "decilla del demonio õmãyãri apenas se escucha"

"The natural English translation for 'decilla del demonio õmãyãri apenas se escucha' is 'the demon's whisper is barely heard'.
Literal: 'demon's whisper barely is heard'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãmoku nini"
"The natural English translation for 'ãmoku nini' is 'my child'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãmoku niniprou"
"The natural English translation for 'ãmoku niniprou' is 'my friend'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãmoku ninimou"
"The natural English translation for 'ãmoku ninimou' is 'my friend'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama"

"The natural English translation for 'rahararitawë a amishiri miã kãi rërëpiapraramama' is 'the children are playing and running around the village'.
Literal: 'Children the village around running playing'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "suwë kë a kiriri ruaprarou ha tikoikuni"

"The natural English translation for 'suwë kë a kiriri ruaprarou ha tikoikuni' is 'the children are playing and running around the village'.
Literal: 'children the village around run play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "suwë kë kipi miã kãi ipihipraropë ha a wãri pakihiapraroma"

The natural English translation for 'suwë kë kipi miã kãi ipihipraropë ha a wãri pakihiapraroma' is 'the children are playing and running around the village'.
Literal: 'Children the village around run play'.
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ã r epo koko pë kãi tëapotayo kuhe"

"The natural English translation for 'ã r epo koko pë kãi tëapotayo kuhe' is 'I'm going to the village to get some banana fruit'.
Literal: 'I go village banana fruit get come'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "mapë ãhã hititiapotayoma"

"The natural English translation for 'mapë ãhã hititiapotayoma' is 'you are very beautiful'.
Literal: 'You very beautiful'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãpuru uﬁ"
"The natural English translation for 'ãpuru uﬁ' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya pë taeaprarai"
"The natural English translation for 'ya pë taeaprarai' is 'you are a good hunter'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "enaha rë e thë pë pëaprarai kuaama, e thë hõãprarai kuaama"

"The natural English translation for 'enaha rë e thë pë pëaprarai kuaama, e thë hõãprarai kuaama' is 'today we will go to the gardens to harvest banana and sugarcane'.
Literal: 'Today we go banana garden, sugarcane garden'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "kõã yama ãyõ pë thai"

"The natural English translation for 'kõã yama ãyõ pë thai' is 'the child is eating banana'.
Literal: 'child banana eating is'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãrepo pë kãi tëapotayouhe"

"The natural English translation for 'ãrepo pë kãi tëapotayouhe' is 'the children are playing outside'.
Literal: 'Children outside play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "Kõã hesi ãsho koa hesi."
"The natural English translation for 'Kõã hesi ãsho koa hesi' is 'I'm going to the river to fish'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãrepo kë pë ta yoahe, pëmaki ta iya"

"The natural English translation for 'ãrepo kë pë ta yoahe, pëmaki ta iya' is 'The children are playing, they are having fun'.
Literal: 'Children the they play, they laugh'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "Ẽ koko a kõkõri"

"The natural English translation for 'Ẽ koko a kõkõri' is 'I am cooking banana'.
Literal: 'I cook banana'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "orawë koko"
"The natural English translation for 'orawë koko' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "aroami kë ki oraki rë yareheikiyohe ë yë!"
"The natural English translation for 'aroami kë ki oraki rë yareheikiyohe ë yë!' is 'Don't go near that dangerous snake over there!'"
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ya miõhërii"
"The natural English translation for 'ya miõhërii' is 'I'm hungry'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "a patahërii"
"The natural English translation for 'a patahërii' is 'I'm hungry'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "u resiahërii"
"The natural English translation for 'u resiahërii' is 'you are sick'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "shu. huko wãri rë ãrõkiwei a wãri rë përiope"
"The natural English translation for 'shu. huko wãri rë ãrõkiwei a wãri rë përiope' is 'Hush. The children are sleeping and the children are resting'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãrõkiã"
"The natural English translation for 'ãrõkiã' is 'thank you'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãrõkima no"
"The natural English translation for 'ãrõkima no' is 'good morning'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "poreriyoma horema kë pëni thë ãmoku mi wathëaprai kupariyoma, pë thë ãsiri misi rukëi no kureshi"

"The natural English translation for 'poreriyoma horema kë pëni thë ãmoku mi wathëaprai kupariyoma, pë thë ãsiri misi rukëi no kureshi' is 'The children are playing in the river, catching small fish with their hands'.
Literal: 'Children river in fish small hands with catching playing, and water in swimming not knowing'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "thë posi he yohoporani, pitha hami thë aruku pata ha shaiprarani thë mo tititai yairayoma"

"The natural English translation for 'thë posi he yohoporani, pitha hami thë aruku pata ha shaiprarani thë mo tititai yairayoma' is 'The sun is very hot today, so we will go to the river to bathe and cool off in the refreshing water'."

Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ambures pertenecientes a las especies paushimi o rõkõmi que aún no están completamente maduros, y que se ponen a secar, verdes y pelados, por encima del fuego"

"The natural English translation for 'ambures pertenecientes a las especies paushimi o rõkõmi que aún no están completamente maduros, y que se ponen a secar, verdes y pelados, por encima del fuego' is 'unripe paushimi or rõkõmi fruits that are put to dry, green and peeled, over the fire'.

I'm uncertain about the exact translation as this does not appear to be a Yanomami phrase. It seems to be in Spanish referring to certain fruit varieties."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "hei ihiru kë pë rõkõmipi wãrimou rë kupe"

"The natural English translation for 'hei ihiru kë pë rõkõmipi wãrimou rë kupe' is 'the children are playing with the new blowgun'.
Literal: 'Children those new blowgun with play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "maa maki pata tuyëihe, ãshãkãre e ma pë wai shirõ prariroma"

"The natural English translation for 'maa maki pata tuyëihe, ãshãkãre e ma pë wai shirõ prariroma' is 'When the sun goes down, we will go to the river to fish with bows and arrows'.
Literal: 'Sun goes down, we go to river fish with bows arrows'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãshãkãre hi"
"The natural English translation for 'ãshãkãre hi' is 'thank you'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãshãkãre mahiki rë kui, yaraka pë kuprariyoma"
"The natural English translation for 'ãshãkãre mahiki rë kui, yaraka pë kuprariyoma' is 'The children are playing, making a lot of noise'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãtãri ya ãhi mi rë hatukëare, ya kipi nohi haruhupou totihio yaro"

The natural English translation for 'ãtãri ya ãhi mi rë hatukëare, ya kipi nohi haruhupou totihio yaro' is 'Yesterday I went to the river to fish, but I didn't catch any fish'.
Literal: 'Yesterday I go river fish, I not catch fish any'.
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "ãtãri ya ãhi këprarema"

"The natural English translation for 'ãtãri ya ãhi këprarema' is 'the children are playing'.
Literal: 'Children they play'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "enaha rë ãhi rii kuwë, ãhi rii akatahuprai waikirayou kuhahei"
"The natural English translation for 'enaha rë ãhi rii kuwë, ãhi rii akatahuprai waikirayou kuhahei' is 'Yesterday I went to the river, I went to fish with a hook and line'."
Translate this Yanomami phrase to English: "a wãri ãtiãmi, pë wãri waikoma tao"
